metadata.title: What are AI Models? | AI Models Explained
metadata.author: Glide

transcript: We use AI for so much, for writing emails, summarizing reports, and even recommending what we eat. But behind all that magic, there is something called an AI model. If you ever wonder what models like GPD4, Claude, or Gymnite actually do, and how to choose the right one, this video is for you. And if you're thinking about building your own AI tools like smart assistant, a content generator, or a lead scoring app, I'll show you how platforms like Thrive actually do that without writing a single line of code. Let's dive in. An AM model is like a digital brain trains of ton of information. You ask it a question or give it a task and it gives you a response. That could be a piece of writing, a summary, an image, code, anything. But not all AI models are the same. Each one has different strengths, weaknesses, and ideal uses. Let's say you are building something with AI, like a customer support bot or a tool to organize your sales lead. Do you want it to answer fast, handle long documents, be great at writing? Different goals call for different models. Start by asking, what do I need this AI to do? Does it need to be fast, accurate, or cost effective? Am I working with private or sensitive data? Do I need deep reasoning or just a quick short answers? Once you're clear on what you need, choosing the right model becomes much easier. Let's take a look at some of the most widely used AI models today and what they are each designed to do. This will help you understand the range of capabilities out there and how different models are built with different goals in mind. GBD4 by OpenAI, a general purpose model built for deep reasoning, writing and complex tasks. Often used for research, coding, or anything that needs accuracy and context. Three, bionthropic. This is great for summarizing documents and maintaining a helpful balanced tone. Popular in customer support and document heavy use cases. Gemini 1.5 by Google. A multimodel model, meaning it can understand images, video, and text all at once. Used in tools that combine visual and written inputs. Mistral by Mistl AI. Open- source, lightweight, and designed for speed and efficiency. Often chosen for the smaller apps or when cost is a factor. Deepseek by DeepSci. Designed for technical tasks like math and code. It's a good fit for tools that requisi built for real-time responses using current web data. still evolving, but aim at use cases where up to the info is key. These are just a few examples of the most talked about models right now. Each one is optimized for different goals. So, understanding what you need is key before picking one. There's a big difference between just using AI and actually integrating it with into a tool or workflow. If you are building a software for your team or business, picking the right model is a big deal. Do you go with GBD4, HUD, Mistral? Which one is faster, safer, cheaper? That's where Glide comes in. Glide automatically selects the best model for your use case, whether it's summarizing text, classifying data, or generating content and connect you to the enterprisegrade version that's far secure and your data is never used for training. Once the model is set, you can build apps that put the AI power directly in your user's hands, whether it's internal teams or customers. Now, this means smarter inputs, a system workflows, or dynamic features, all inside your own custom software. No code required. So to recap, a models are the brains behind most modern tools. Each one has unique strengths. Pick based on what you need. And if you want to build with AI without being a developer, BL makes it possible. Did this help? Hit a like and subscribe for more videos about AI automation and building smart businesses. Got questions? Drop them in the comments. I'll read them all. I'll see you in the next one. key_facts: AI models are digital brains trained on large amounts of information.
Different AI models have distinct strengths and ideal use cases.
AI can be used for writing emails, summarizing reports, and food recommendations.
An AI model responds to tasks with outputs like text, code, or images.
Choosing an AI model depends on required speed, accuracy, or cost efficiency.
Some AI models handle long documents better than others.
Private or sensitive data considerations affect model selection.
Deep reasoning needs differ from quick-answer requirements in AI models.
GPT-4 by OpenAI supports deep reasoning, writing, and complex tasks.
Claude by Anthropic excels at document summarization and tone balance.
Gemini 1.5 by Google processes images, video, and text simultaneously.
Mistral by Mistral AI is open-source and optimized for speed and efficiency.
Deepseek by DeepSeek focuses on technical tasks such as math and coding.
Perplexity AI delivers real-time responses using current web data.
AI models vary in their training data, architecture, and performance focus.
Integrating AI into workflows differs from casual usage.
Model choice impacts security, speed, and cost in business applications.
Glide selects optimal AI models based on specific use cases.
Enterprise-grade AI versions offer enhanced security and privacy.
User data in enterprise AI is not used for model training.
Custom AI apps can be built without coding via platforms like Glide.
AI-powered features include smarter inputs and dynamic workflows.
AI integration enables internal team or customer-facing tools.
The video aims to explain AI models and no-code AI tool building.
Content covers major models including GPT-4, Claude, Gemini, Mistral.
key_opinions: Understanding your AI goal makes model selection easier.
Picking the right AI model is crucial when building software.
Speed, safety, and cost should guide AI model decisions.
Using AI effectively requires clarity on task requirements.
No-code platforms democratize AI application development.
Balanced tone in responses is valuable for customer support.
Real-time information access is key for certain AI applications.
Open-source models offer flexibility and cost advantages.
Multimodal capability adds value in visual-textual applications.
Accuracy matters most in research and coding tasks.
Lightweight models suit small-scale or budget-conscious apps.
Enterprise security is essential for sensitive deployments.
Automated model selection simplifies AI integration.
Custom AI tools empower end users directly.
Building AI tools without code lowers entry barriers.
Video content helps demystify AI model differences.
Summarization ability is critical for document-heavy uses.
Fast response time enhances user experience in bots.
Cost-effectiveness should be weighed against performance.
Developers aren't required to build functional AI apps.
Model specialization beats general-purpose use in some cases.
AI adoption benefits from clear use-case alignment.
Businesses gain efficiency through tailored AI workflows.
Viewers are encouraged to engage via likes and subscriptions.
Comments will be read and considered by the creator.
key_datapoints: GPT-4 is developed by OpenAI.
Claude is created by Anthropic.
Gemini 1.5 is a product of Google.
Mistral is developed by Mistral AI.
Deepseek is built by DeepSeek company.
Perplexity AI uses real-time web data.
Gemini handles multimodal inputs: text, image, video.
Mistral is open-source.
Mistral is lightweight and efficient.
Deepseek specializes in math and code tasks.
Enterprise-grade AI ensures higher security.
No-code platforms enable app creation without programming.
AI models process private data securely in enterprise mode.
Platforms like Glide automate model selection.
Custom apps can integrate AI for internal teams.
Customer-facing AI tools can be built without code.
AI supports lead scoring application development.
Content generators can be implemented via no-code tools.
Smart assistants are feasible without coding.
Document summarization is a common AI use case.
Coding assistance is a primary function of GPT-4.
Research tasks benefit from accurate AI models.
Real-time data use is a goal for evolving AI systems.
Video targets users interested in AI automation.
Audience is invited to comment and subscribe.
